title: Quiz 3: Regional Casts & Clinical Indications
description: Assess your knowledge of specific regional casts, splint types, and their clinical indications.

questions.question: Which cast is indicated for a Scaphoid (Navicular) fracture?
questions.explanation: A Thumb Spica immobilizes the thumb and wrist, which is necessary for scaphoid fractures.

questions.question: A Short Arm Cast typically extends distally to which landmark?
questions.explanation: It stops at the distal palmar crease to allow full flexion of the MCP joints (knuckles).
questions.hint: Allows you to make a fist.

questions.question: Which movement does a Long Arm Cast prevent that a Short Arm Cast does NOT?
questions.explanation: By including the elbow, a Long Arm Cast controls forearm rotation (pronation/supination).

questions.question: Match the splint/cast with its common indication:
questions.explanation: Sugar Tong -> Colles; Spica -> Scaphoid; Long Arm -> Forearm shaft; Cylinder -> Knee.
questions.hint: Think about the body part immobilized.

questions.question: A 'Hanging Cast' requires immobilization of the shoulder and elbow to be effective.
questions.explanation: The Hanging Cast relies on gravity/traction and does NOT immobilize the shoulder; it allows some motion to promote healing.

questions.question: Which of the following are types of Upper Extremity Splints? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Posterior Leg and Stirrup are for the lower extremity.
questions.hint: Which ones go on the arm?

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ cast extends from the groin to the toes and immobilizes the knee and ankle.
questions.explanation: A Long Leg cast covers the entire leg from upper thigh (groin) to foot.

questions.question: What is the primary function of a 'Slab'?

options.text: To provide temporary support/accommodation for swelling

questions.explanation: Slabs (splints) do not encircle the limb, allowing for swelling in the acute phase.

questions.question: Identify the cast shown in the description: 'Extends from just proximal to the knuckles, up the dorsal forearm, around the elbow, and down the volar forearm.'

richContent.content: Features: U-shaped splint, prevents rotation, used for wrist fractures.

questions.explanation: This describes the Sugar Tong splint.

questions.question: Order the parts of a Long Arm Cast from proximal to distal:
questions.explanation: Top of arm -> Elbow -> Forearm -> Hand.

questions.question: A Short Leg Cast immobilizes the knee joint.
questions.explanation: A Short Leg Cast starts BELOW the knee, leaving the knee free.
questions.hint: Does it go above the knee?

questions.question: Which cast is used for stable fractures of the distal humerus?
questions.explanation: A Long Arm Cast immobilizes the elbow and distal humerus.
questions.hint: It needs to cover the humerus.

questions.question: What does the term 'Spica' refer to in casting?
questions.explanation: Spica refers to the figure-of-eight or spiral bandaging technique used at the junction of the trunk and extremity.

questions.question: Select the fractures commonly treated with a Long Leg Cast:
questions.explanation: Long Leg casts are for unstable fractures of the tibia, fibula, or distal femur where knee immobilization is required.

questions.question: What is a 'Cylinder Cast'?

options.text: A cast from groin to ankle, leaving the foot free
A cast that covers the whole body

questions.explanation: A Cylinder cast is a tube from upper thigh to ankle, immobilizing the knee but leaving the foot/ankle free.
questions.hint: Like a tube on the leg.
